Award.AwardTitle: Towards a Sustainable Management of Insect Collections in the U.S. through the Entomological Collections Management Workshop
Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural history collections are repositories of biological specimens and their associated information. They document Earth's biodiversity in the past, present, and hold species that are new to science. These collections make invaluable contributions to the classification of organisms, and more broadly to public health and safety and security of natural and agricultural resources. They are also tools for monitoring environmental change that affect the human condition. Entomological collections are especially important because insects represent the most diverse and abundant group of animals. Insects are ubiquitous in our everyday lives, with more than a million species worldwide. Insect collections are organized and maintained only through specialized knowledge and experience of curators and collections managers which has historically passed directly from one curator or collection manager to the next since no formal program existed to do this in a broader, more comprehensive fashion. This generational knowledge transfer is especially amplified at small to medium-sized collections, representing ~70% of all insect collections in the U.S. Despite their size, these collections are often extremely valuable because of strong regional, ecological or geographic foci. Currently, there is no training program available in collections management for insect collections, suggesting that an urgent need exists to develop a comprehensive program in best management practices for small to medium-sized collections. Such a program would also provide a much-needed networking opportunity for collections managers at different career stages and at different sized institutions to interact and share their experience and knowledge.

This award supports the first Entomological Collections Management Workshop Series, co-sponsored by the Entomological Collections Network (ECN) and the Systematics, Evolution, and Biodiversity (SysEB) Section of the Entomological Society of America (ESA). The inaugural workshop is scheduled to take place at the National Museum of Natural History, Washington, DC, on July 18-20, 2016, and continue annually thereafter. During the three-day workshop, participants will receive hands-on training in entomological collections management topics including collections management policies, specimen handling, curation, storage, conservation and more. This project will encourage participation of collections managers and students associated with smaller collections with more limited resources for training and collection development. This workshop will especially help the largest and fastest growing segment of underserved groups of students and early career researchers, including females, Latinos, African Americans, and Native Americans, by providing opportunities for professional development leading to a higher skilled, technically-trained workforce. The results of this workshop will be posted on the ECN website at http://ecnweb.org/default.asp?Action=Show_Workshop and presented at the ECN annual meeting in Orlando, FL on September 23-24, 2016.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the inaugural Entomological Collections Management Workshop series for three years (2016, 2017, 2018). Co-sponsored by the Entomological Collections Network (ECN) and the Systematics, Evolution, and the Biodiversity (SysEB) section of the Entomological Society of America (ESA), this workshop series was organized in response to a growing and unmet need by the entomological collections community for a structured, standardized training program on all aspects of management and promotion of entomological collections. Specifically, this workshop series was designed with the target of broadening participation for collection managers and students, especially those associated with small collections, who might have limited resources to develop their collections and their staff.

The first workshop was held at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History, Washington, DC, on July 18-20, 2016 with 22 attendees. The second workshop was held at the Milwaukee Public Museum (MPM) and the Field Museum of Natural History (FMNH) on July 17-20, 2017 with 23 attendees. The final workshop was held at the California Academy of Sciences (CAS) and the Essig Museum of Entomology at UC Berkeley on July 23-26, 2018 with 26 attendees. The workshop locations were selected purposefully to from across the U.S. to make it easier for individuals from across the country to participate without the added burden of additional travel costs.  Over the three years, this project provided direct financial support for registration, travel, and lodging for 48 participants who lacked institutional support to participate (12 in 2016, 16 in 2017, and 20 in 2018). No part of the award supported instructor travel or course expenses, which were covered solely through student registration. 

Over the course of each workshop, participants were exposed to theoretical and practical issues related to management of entomological collections, which often pose unique challenges owing to their size, scope, age, geographic distribution, etc.  Workshops covered a range of topics including collections management policies, conservation and pest management, collections digitization and data management, specimen preparation, storage and housing materials, collection profiling and assessment, and how to manage up, down and laterally when interacting with other museum staff, the general public and decision-makers/stakeholders. 

Most entomology collections staff come from a research background with little to no formal training or experience in managing collections, which requires a completely different set of skills than using collections for research.  The primary goal was of course to provide better and more standardized training in entomological collections management that was not available anywhere else, but it had the added benefit of creating three cohorts of collections professionals that will continue to network with the instructors and with each other after they complete the course. 

This workshop series represented the first of its kind specifically designed to develop human resources necessary for managing entomological collections. The total number of participants over the three years, excluding the 2 main instructors but including guest lecturers from each of the host institutions, was 105 from 56 institutions representing private and public museums, universities (both small and land-grant), national parks, nature reserves, federal agencies, as well as foreign institutions. As such, this workshop series has trained and produced a large workforce for entomological collections management, which will have a major impact for the future of natural history collections as they take what they learned back to their respective organizations and train others.
